The bang-bang relays of the multiple-boiler system (MBS) control, are characterized by complex limiter saturation functions and classified as fixed parameters. Their action signals cannot precisely control the nonlinear dynamic building heating demand over their entire range of operation. Moreover, in a mono-boiler system, the bang-bang controller endures increasing short cycling over partial load time due to the heating system being considered to have an oversized boiler at most times of running, thus promoting high energy consumption and fluctuating indoor thermal comfort. So, it is difficult to cope with uncertainties in outdoor environments and indoor heating load. Hence, this study formulates the MBS control problem as a dynamic Markov decision process and applies a deep clustering of reinforcement learning approach to obtain the optimal control policy through interaction with the environment based on multi-agent learning according to bang-bang action. With such an approach, adopting a new boiler sequencing control (BSC) strategy using deep clustering of reinforcement learning based on a bang-bang (DCRLBB) manner. The deep clustering is configured to break Lagrangian trajectory curves into piecewise segments to represent the RL agent's action policy. The agent's action policy signals are configured from the bang-bang reward formula based on trade-off implications to be more adjustable than traditional fixed parameters such as fuzzy bang-bang controller (FBBC). The agent of BSC significantly affects the energy performance of the MBS, whereas the other agent resizes boiler capacity by acting to adjust the boiler solenoid fuel valve. The comparison of results between the proposed strategy and conventional FBBC shows distinct differences in the superior response of DCRLBB under dynamic indoor/outdoor actual conditions and energy saving by more than 32% while maintaining the indoor thermal in the comfortable range. Introduction In buildings, the heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems generally comprise 45–50% of total energy consumption [1,2]. The boiler heating loads are the most important factor in HVAC systems affected by direct emissions from burning fuels, which is significantly affected by the energy performance of the multiple-boiler system (MBS) [3]. Fuels demand response (DR) in boilers, along with greenhouse gas emissions, is considered a vital flexibility enabler in reducing consuming energy and carbon emission to increase the performance of controller action and the flexibility of the HVAC system [4,5]. Many studies present the potential for energy saving in boiler plants and achieved through improving heating system controls [6]. The most concern in building heating systems is that often-used boilers are much oversized to provide a substantial margin of heating load capacity, leading to inefficient management by conventional boiler controllers [7–12]. In control engineering, a single-input and single-output (SISO) type is still widely used to control boiler plants and HVAC systems automation [13,14]. The most common type of such algorithm is the proportional-integral-derivative (PID), which is found in more than 90% of industrial control applications using feedback control loops of PID [15]. The simplicity of PID attracted most scientists to be used in automatic control, and this feature helps be a popular control. Therefore, the PID is considered imperative to be used at the lowest control level in the pyramid hierarchy of boilers and HVAC control systems [16,17]. The PID fails with processes running too-high nonlinear systems and MIMO (multiple inputs, multiple outputs) systems in multi-boiler systems. The classical bang-bang controller still has advantages and is adopted by most control techniques due to enabling the control of nonlinear systems [18,19]. The classical bang-bang controller made from electromechanical relays is becoming obsolete and acting slowly due to their fixed parameters [20,21]. Some drawbacks in the bang-bang relay controller are addressed by converting fuzzy logic controllers, such as fuzzy bang–bang controller (FBBC), which gives a better response [22,23]. However, traditional bang-bang control or On/Off strategy for boiler systems cannot precisely follow dynamic building heating demand, so the parameters are manipulated to track its set point [24]. The optimal sequencing control of a boiler plant in a bang-bang manner is challenging since it is the largest related to controlling hot water temperature [25]. The programmable logic controller (PLC) is widely used to manage the sequencing of the MBS to significantly reduce consumption energy while satisfying indoor thermal comfort [26]. However, the PLC needs a state machine of a dead band to trigger whether the boilers are online or offline and thus need to be constantly adjusted [27]. Therefore, the conventional method for controlling boiler sequencing involves modifying the dead band, or hysteresis, surrounding the set-point [28]. This approach effectively manages concerns such as chattering and harmonic switching on/off, as illustrated in Fig. 1 . Fig. 1 depicts a graphical representation of the phenomena, showcasing the correlation between the time axis and the dependent variable of thresholds. Upon analyzing the profile illustrated in Fig. 1, it is evident that the current heating load of the structure impacts the points that dictate the activation and deactivation of the boilers. The temperature set-point is maintained by dynamically adjusting the thresholds in response to fluctuations in the heating load [29,30]. Implementing this modification is crucial to avert the swift and superfluous oscillation of the boilers, thereby mitigating the detrimental effects of wear and tear, energy dissipation, and related operational complications. The boiler sequencing control (BSC) method can effectively reduce the undesirable effects of chattering and harmonic switching by introducing a dead band around the set-point. The dead band is a designated interval that allows variations in the heating load to occur without requiring frequent adjustments to the boiler's operation [31]. Implementing this methodology guarantees heightened stability and efficacy in regulating the heating system, enhancing its functionality, and minimizing superfluous boiler cycling. Reinforcement learning (RL) is suitable for use in MIMO systems applications, a type of machine learning concerned with how intelligent agents learn based on an interactive environment by trial and error using feedback from their own actions sets and experiences [32,33]. Despite the RL being able to optimize control action and get the proper decision-making for problems with environmental uncertainties, the performance of pure RL controllers was inefficient based on the investigation done by many studies [34–36]. Therefore, some researchers have adopted deep reinforcement learning (DRL) in pure RL to obtain the optimal agent action policy through interaction with the environment [37]. The DRL effectively guides the agent towards the optimal control policy while improving the robustness and consistency of overall test scenarios with a sufficient convergence rate. Each agent interacts with its environment in discrete time steps to learn a policy, where two approaches have been adopted: stochastic and deterministic [38]. In the stochastic case, the policy gradient integrates over both state and action spaces, whereas in the deterministic case, it only integrates over the state space [39]. As a result, computing the stochastic policy gradient may require more samples, especially if the action space has many dimensions [40]. The reward function effectively guides the multi-agent multi-objective to learn from interactions. The multi-agent framework can be divided into three separate kinds of strategies: I. Cooperative: Agents learn individually to achieve the same objective, share the reward according to their achievements, or learn to get the same reward. II. Competitive: Agents learn individually to compete with each other for their objectives, and the reward to an agent means the loss of others. III. Mixed: Agents may learn individually to cooperate under some conditions; otherwise, they compete. This study adopts the first type of multi-agent reinforcement learning; one of them is the hub agent of the control centers that are used to guide the BSC, and the others are one for each boiler to resize its capacity by acting to adjust the boiler solenoid fuel valve. Such a framework enables the reward function to optimize the multi-objective problem by distributing decision policies for agents according to interactions with each other; individual or single agents cannot achieve this. Based on the above observation in the literature, this paper presents the proposed concept of improving the cooperative multi-agent policy. Furthermore, it shows the new strategy of multi-boiler based on the proposed controller more suitable for intelligent buildings than a mono boiler type. The deep clustering is integrated with the RL-based collaborative multi-agent approach according to bang-bang action to deal with continuous action spaces. The boiler sequencing control (BSC) problem can be formulated as a Markov decision process in dynamic environments, and the DCRLBB technique is proposed to optimize the boiler plant operation. The main contributions of DCRLBB are summarized as follows: 1. The proposed strategy of multi-boiler based on DCRLBB exhibits superior sample efficiency and minimizes short cycling on oversized boilers. 2. A DCRLBB mechanism is devised, which guides the BSC agent to obtain the optimal control policy towards low energy consumption without sacrificing occupant comfort. The DCRLBB mechanism is applied to design a reasonable overall evaluation indicator for quantitative evaluation of the performance of control methods. 3. DCRLBB provides a viable approach to handling various multi-agent cooperative policies and can represent an extensive training dataset. 4. Implementing the clustering technique helps well-fit the Lagrangian model to express optimal agent policy. 5. Online learning for active decision-making facilitates the agent to predict a multi-boiler's power demand and reduce boiler plants' energy consumption by more than 32%. 2 Description of the model and problem statement To evaluate the proposed DCRLBB performance, it is crucial to create a combined model of building and HVAC systems to adjust the problem statement as follows: 2.1 Building and boiler systems modeling The thermophysical properties of building materials cannot express actual indoor conditions when used by modeling. The sequential steps are the initial mapping step of the RL policy, the clustering step, and the Lagrangian identification step. 3.1 DCRLBB policy generation based on CMAS The proposed bang-bang controller is suitable for multi-objective optimization and cooperative multi-agent systems (CMAS). This subsection focuses on generating an optimal policy curriculum for RL CMAS, which leads to efficiently managing HVAC systems to lower costs. The AHU of variable air volume (VAV) type is adopted to assist the HVAC systems in reducing cooling demand at mild temperature days by reducing the amount of airflow and thus achieving energy-efficient thermal comfort [48–50]. The controllable or independent variables in the proposed model are defined by finite state space, and finite the action space to the agents of the RL algorithm to be the connection between the inputs and outputs of the model. Where the actions of multi-agent or CMAS are manipulated, the positions of the primary/pre-cooling coil valve, tune dampers position in the VAV system, On/Off mechanical ventilation, open/close windows, On/Off light, etc. After each action, the immediate reward value is returned due to the act of the state transition probability (p) to a specific position (s), where the state represents indoor thermal comfort level (according to set-point) and energy saving, which maximizes the V ∗ value by executing Bellman Eq. (7). The sensation of indoor thermal comfort is significantly affected by operative temperature and RH; accordingly, the RL learning used them as independent variables for the value function of states. The indoor operative temperature and RH are vital variables to calculate the predicted mean vote (PMV) value, confirmed following ISO7730 and ASHRAE standards [51–53]. Setting the set-point of state value according to the ASHRAE standard of the lower and upper bound helps to exploit such a range by reducing cooling demand at mild outdoor temperatures. And sometimes shuts down HVAC systems in the early morning to avoid excessive energy waste. The pseudocode steps of agent-environment interaction over state transition probability to get the tuple values of the optimal policy are presented in Table 2 . 3.2 Structure of deep clustering After generating the policy, the weights of the CMAS actions are updated recursively, as stated by the RL algorithm. Deep clustering is a method that adopts multi-hidden layer neural networks to express the clustering technique. The categorization of deep clustering techniques can be divided into three primary categories: network loss, deep neural network (DNN), and clustering loss. The present investigation reveals that the dataset lacks organization regarding separate clusters. Consequently, hybrid DNN clustering is implemented to enhance the performance of the deep form. This is achieved by clustering an entire agent's action into groups of similar data points without supervision or prior knowledge of the rule. The center locations of the agent's multi-dimensional clusters are determined using a c-means algorithm. The fundamental methodology employed by c-means involves the allocation of each data point { Y i c } within the feature space to a specific cluster. The algorithm generates c cluster centers, each corresponding to a cluster, by computing the mean values of the coordinates of the points assigned to it. The present study concerns the clustering task that involves partitioning the data space {U}, U = {u 1 , u 2 , … u K }, into a family of clusters {Ci}, where i = 1,2 … c, and where [2 ≤ c ≤ K]. The set-theoretic equations that express this clustering task are as follows: (11) Y i = 1 c C i = U The neural networks' weights produced by the Lagrangian formula are systemised in a matrix form according to the dynamic memory cells, where each matrix (layer) represents the cluster weights. The weight layers of memory cells are fabricated and well-arranged by a Lagrangian structure based on the nonlinear technique. These layers are adjusted to be suitable for manipulating the input parameters as an agent action [54]. Each agent action of CMAS is broken up into five or more clusters depending on the behavior of the agent action. The variables in dynamic memory cells are initiated by training offline based on model responses to the introduced RL scheme of CMAS. The tuning process is implemented using the optimisation algorithm of Quasi-Newton (QN). Then, online adaptive dynamic weights via fine-tuning are necessary to reform the action weights to change the state's situation into the right position. The online adaptive of QN adopted a feedforward tuning approach, thus being faster in response to CMAS actions. The structure of the weights layers is flexible to be expanded for increasing additional weights, and such a feature helps to deal with large-scale actions with high-dimensional datasets, as demonstrated in Fig. 6 . The facilities for the expansion of the three-dimension structure of weights allow increasing independent variables based on a highly correlated matrix. In addition to the three-dimension design, time is the effective fourth one. Each independent input variable is related to time due to cooling and heating load affected by time, as shown in Fig. 4. The initial values of the Lagrangian weight box model, which were obtained by offline learning, significantly reduced the online tuning time due to starting learning from its value instead of setting it to zero values. Examining these fluctuations enhances the boiler system's functionality, guaranteeing adequate energy consumption and a pleasant indoor thermal ambiance. 4.2 Reward-based on bang–bang (on/off) The present study centers on producing the output reward within the context of reinforcement learning (RL) through implementing a binary (on/off) strategy. The current methodology is specifically implemented to control the sequencing of boilers (referred to as boilers sequencing control or BSC). The primary objective is to determine the optimal mode by utilizing a predetermined threshold value trigger. The operational mechanism of the bang-bang agent involves alternating various boiler modes in response to the attainment of a specific threshold value by the indoor condition. At the outset, the agent functions in mode 1, employing a solitary boiler. Upon exceeding the threshold value, the agent transitions to mode 2, utilizing a pair of boilers for heating. If the threshold value experiences an increase, the agent will proceed to transition into mode 3, which involves the utilization of three boilers. The dead band is the mathematical expression that characterizes the operating fraction of the bang-bang agent in a state of zero sensitivity. The bang-bang agent is a reinforcement learning agent that acquires the ability to regulate a given system by alternately selecting between two distinct actions: activation and deactivation. The bang-bang agent can learn to alternate between one, two, and three boilers in the context of boiler sequencing control to regulate the indoor temperature to remain within a predetermined range. The training of the bang-bang agent involves utilizing a reward function specifically formulated to incentivize the agent to transition to the appropriate mode upon attaining a predetermined threshold value for indoor temperature. The agent operating the bang-bang approach acquires knowledge of maximizing the reward function through experimentation and learning from errors. The agent's learning process enhances its ability to transition to the appropriate mode at the optimal moment, reducing energy consumption and improving indoor comfort levels. The significance of the operating fraction of the dead band lies in its potential impact on the energy efficiency of the sequencing system of the boiler. Increasing the active fraction of the dead band is likely to result in reduced energy consumption. However, this may also lead to a decrease in indoor comfort. The measure of the frequency with which the bang-bang agent transitions between modes is represented by the dead band operating fraction. A discount factor of 0 indicates that the agent is only concerned with immediate rewards, whereas a discount factor of 1 indicates that the agent is equally concerned with primary and future rewards. It is vital because it allows the agent to learn a long-term policy that maximizes its long-term return. A study was conducted to illustrate the impact of the discount factor on average rewards; the results are depicted in Fig. 13 . The investigation involved collecting samples from one hundred to two thousand iterations. It was observed that the average reward stabilizes at 1.05 when it is set to 0. This demonstrates that the agent makes decisions with a myopic focus on immediate rewards, disregarding long-term benefits or repercussions. When the discount factor is set to 1, indicating that all future rewards are given equal weight, the average reward stabilizes at a higher value of 1.35. This implies that the agent evaluates rewards from the entire range of samples (from 600 to 2000), giving equal weight to immediate and future rewards. Intriguingly, when the discount factor is set to 0.98, the average reward increases from 1.1 to 1.4 between 100 and 2000 samples. By setting it to 0.98, a compromise was reached between the distant and near future in this study. This value enables the agent to establish a balance between considering future rewards and immediate rewards, increasing the average reward as the agent gains experience from more samples. This study examined the discount factor's effect on an RL agent's performance when performing a primary task. A robot was tasked with navigating a maze to achieve an objective. It was discovered that the agent's efficacy improved as the discount factor increased. This is because the agent learned a policy that accounted for the future rewards it would receive for achieving the objective. In addition, it was discovered that the agent's efficacy peaked when the discount factor was 0.98. The agent maintained a balance between focusing on immediate and long-term rewards. If the discount factor had been too low, the agent would have focused solely on immediate rewards and would not have been able to learn a policy that would allow it to achieve the objective. If the discount factor had been excessively high, the agent would have been overly concerned with long-term gains and too reticent to take risks. The selection of the discount factor is a compromise between the agent's emphasis on immediate and long-term rewards. A higher discount factor will encourage the agent to prioritize long-term rewards, whereas a lower discount factor will encourage the agent to prioritize immediate rewards. The optimal discount factor will vary based on the task the agent attempts to master. In reinforcement learning (RL), the agent acquires knowledge by carrying out a series of actions, resulting in outputs influencing the value process. Refining the value function is believed to be an effective method for obtaining optimal decision-making principles—RL functions as the basis for establishing the value operation's framework. In practical applications, however, the value function may be subject to inaccuracies and disturbances because of uncertainties. Consequently, enhancing the value formula to rectify these discrepancies and resolve any inherent flaws is essential. The value function's structure depends on the extent of discretization learning employed. The optimal number of the discretization levels required for a given task is identified through repeated learning iterations. Fig. 14 illustrates the variation in the value function resulting from two distinct discretization numbers. The value function for RL defines the state's value (v) and plays a crucial role in directing the bang-bang action's operation. Fig. 14a depicts the relationship between the state (V) value function for RL, the returned water temperature, and the daily operation duration when the optimal value function is obtained for N1 = 13 episodes. At 14:00, the maximal state value coincides with a return water temperature of 46 °C. In contrast, the lowest value is recorded between 1:00 and 6:00 a.m., when the returned water temperature ranges from 10 to 22 degrees Celsius. Fig. 14b depicts the same parameters with a different value of N1 (N1 = 28 episodes) to represent an alternative scenario. This comparison demonstrates the effect of varying the number of episodes on the value function, water temperature returned, and operation duration. Generally, it is crucial in RL to optimize the value function to reduce inaccuracies caused by uncertainties and disturbances. The number of discretization levels utilized during learning significantly impacts the value function's structure. The figures illustrate how varying discretization episode values can affect the relationship between the value function, returned water temperature, and operation time. These results highlight the significance of selecting the optimal number of episodes for optimal performance in RL applications. Multi-boiler plants can be an alternative to a single-boiler system in situations where chattering and harmonic switching)on/off(of the boiler solenoid fuel valve are problems. This method aims to maximize heat transfer while reducing short cycling. To speed up transitions between states and reduce energy consumption, the proposed technique, known as boilers sequencing control (BSC), sequentially operates numerous boilers. The BSC system can efficiently control and sequence boilers in numbers greater than 10. Within a closed threshold value trigger system, this allows for optimal heating and efficient state transfer. The trigger relies on a bang-bang action that has been upgraded with the help of a human agent. As shown in Fig. 15a, the agent's job is to reduce the heating plant's capacity size. In addition, the BSC agent works with another agent to adjust the boiler plant's capacity to meet the heating load requirement. Fig. 15b depicts this coordinated process of adaptation. The detrimental impacts of chattering and harmonic switching, seen in the mono-boiler system, are substantially mitigated by adding a multi-boiler plant and using the BSC method. Using this method, energy efficiency is improved, brief cycling is reduced, and the heating plant's capacity may be precisely controlled in response to the heating load demand. The supplied figures represent the proposed solution, drawing attention to the BSC agent's function in enlarging the heating plant's capacity and the second agent's cooperation in making fine adjustments. These examples support that the method is effective and can potentially solve problems with the mono-boiler setup. In General, a practical approach to reducing short cycling and boosting energy efficiency in a mono-boiler system can be achieved using a multi-boiler plant, deploying the BSC strategy, and collaborative adjustment by two agents. The illustrations illuminate the proposed approach and lend credence to its possible success. The DCRLBB (Dynamic Cooperative Reinforcement Learning for Boiler Control and Sequencing) performance analysis provided valuable insights, showing that the agents' performance improved compared to the baseline method when new strategies were implemented. The analysis of the actions of two cooperating agents, as shown in Fig. 16 , lends credence to this hypothesis. The four scenarios depicted in Fig. 16 are the proposed DCRLBB actions for boiler sequencing, the action of FBBC (Feedback Based Boiler Control) for carrying out the boiler sequencing, the valve position controlled by PID (Proportional-Integral-Derivative) actions, and the time-based on/off control of boilers—show the daily variations in the boiler solenoid fuel valve position and the heating coil load. Observing the valve position under PID control reveals a sinusoidal line with amplitudes and periods that range from 100 to 0. Because PID control constantly adjusts the valve position in response to the difference between the target and actual values, this sort of behavior is to be expected. In contrast, the DCRLBB and FBBC instances proposed here show a sinusoidal line with values between 75% and 0%. These strategies enhance the overall system performance while still assuring efficient operation, so they deviate from the complete range of valve positions. Boiler on/off scheduling, on the other hand, is represented by a positive square curve. When activated, the valve opens to 100%; when deactivated, it closes to 0%. Due to the nature of the control logic, the valve can only be in either the fully open or fully closed position. 5.2 Comparison of indoor conditions with FBBC and mono boiler-based PID The boiler system regulates indoor temperature to ensure optimal comfort levels. The consideration of outdoor thermal comfort is crucial in designing and managing outdoor spaces, particularly in regions that encounter extreme temperatures throughout all four seasons. The Predicted Mean Vote (PMV) is a quantitative index utilized to evaluate human thermal comfort, which considers various meteorological parameters, including air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and solar radiation. The PMV scale encompasses a range of values from −3 to +3. The lower end of the scale, represented by a value of −3, indicates an extremely cold environment, while the upper end, represented by a value of +3, indicates an extremely hot environment. A value of 0 on the PMV scale represents a neutral environment. The Predicted Mean Vote (PMV) index is commonly used to assess thermal comfort in indoor environments. A PMV value ranging from −0.5 to +0.5 typically indicates a pleasant thermal sensation, whereas a PMV value outside this range is generally associated with discomfort. The PMV values for indoor and outdoor areas across various management techniques are depicted throughout the day in Fig. 18 . According to the presented data, it can be observed that the PMV value for the outdoor environment attains its maximum level at 14:00, thereby falling within the range of thermal comfort. Subsequently, the indoor Predicted Mean Vote (PMV) is observed when the boiler is deactivated, exhibiting a similar trend to the outdoor PMV, albeit with distinct numerical values. Upon activation of the boiler system, the PMV is promptly calibrated to 0.5, commonly acknowledged as the optimal level of thermal comfort across various schemes. The DCRLBB control approach yields notably superior outcomes in approximating the comfortable value compared to the FBBZ and PID controls. Outdoor PMV indices can be employed to assess the degree of thermal comfort in open-air environments. The data is crucial in strategizing outdoor pursuits, such as sports competitions or building projects. On the other hand, it can be observed that the PID model demonstrates the maximum power consumption towards the end of the day, indicating the possibility of enhancing its energy optimization techniques. 6 Conclusions The complex limiter saturation functions and fixed parameters of bang-bang relays used in boiler control systems limit their ability to accurately control nonlinear dynamic building heating demand. In mono-boiler systems, the bang-bang controller experiences increased brief cycling during the partial load time, leading to excessive energy consumption and erratic indoor thermal comfort. This study shows that reinforcement learning, specifically the DCLTML algorithm, addresses these issues using multi-agent learning and analog outputs. The results indicate that DCLTML is a viable approach for handling high-dimensional data tasks in large-scale applications. • Using a multi-boiler plant, deploying the BSC strategy, and collaborative adjustment by two agents is a practical approach to lowering short cycling and increasing energy efficiency in a mono-boiler system. The examples clarify the suggested method and provide credibility to its viability. • The results suggest that a method of controlling boiler systems could be to use deep clustering algorithms on Lagrangian trajectory curves. The deep clustering algorithm learned the ideal strategy for managing the boiler system, and the resulting control mechanism kept the interior temperature steady while the exterior temperature fluctuated outside the set point. • A psychrometric chart is a helpful tool for learning about the properties of moist air. This instrument calculates moist air's temperature, humidity, and dew point. Most people will feel most at ease within a specific range of temperatures and relative humidity, and this range is known as the ASHRAE comfort zone. Temperature, humidity, and wind speed are taken into account. • When maintaining comfortable temperatures inside a building, the DCRLBB controller performs admirably. The proposed technique achieves lower MAE, RMSE, and RAE values than the PID and FBBC controllers while showing higher r2 values. The results indicate that the DCRLBB controller is the best alternative for providing ideal interior comfort because of its greater accuracy, precision, and effectiveness in managing temperature. • Suggests that the DCRLBB controller is the best option for controlling the heating load inside a building, as it can maintain the set heating load regardless of changes in ambient temperature. • The DCRLBB model's superiority in reducing energy use over the FBBC and PID approaches. The DCRLBB model displays a regular energy consumption pattern, significantly decreasing daily energy consumption. On the other hand, the PID model shows its highest power use late in the day, suggesting it has room to improve its energy optimization procedures. The DCRLBB method is a promising approach for improving the performance of boiler systems. Future work could focus on improving the efficiency and robustness of this method. Specifically, future work could focus on developing more efficient algorithms for learning the optimal policy, developing strategies for handling uncertainty in the environment, applying the DCRLBB method to other applications in the energy sector, and comparing the performance of the DCRLBB method to other reinforcement learning methods for the boiler control. coredata.dc:description: The bang-bang relays of the multiple-boiler system (MBS) control, are characterized by complex limiter saturation functions and classified as fixed parameters. Their action signals cannot precisely control the nonlinear dynamic building heating demand over their entire range of operation. Moreover, in a mono-boiler system, the bang-bang controller endures increasing short cycling over partial load time due to the heating system being considered to have an oversized boiler at most times of running, thus promoting high energy consumption and fluctuating indoor thermal comfort. So, it is difficult to cope with uncertainties in outdoor environments and indoor heating load. Hence, this study formulates the MBS control problem as a dynamic Markov decision process and applies a deep clustering of reinforcement learning approach to obtain the optimal control policy through interaction with the environment based on multi-agent learning according to bang-bang action. With such an approach, adopting a new boiler sequencing control (BSC) strategy using deep clustering of reinforcement learning based on a bang-bang (DCRLBB) manner. The deep clustering is configured to break Lagrangian trajectory curves into piecewise segments to represent the RL agent's action policy. The agent's action policy signals are configured from the bang-bang reward formula based on trade-off implications to be more adjustable than traditional fixed parameters such as fuzzy bang-bang controller (FBBC). The agent of BSC significantly affects the energy performance of the MBS, whereas the other agent resizes boiler capacity by acting to adjust the boiler solenoid fuel valve. The comparison of results between the proposed strategy and conventional FBBC shows distinct differences in the superior response of DCRLBB under dynamic indoor/outdoor actual conditions and energy saving by more than 32% while maintaining the indoor thermal in the comfortable range.
coredata.dc:title: Deep clustering of reinforcement learning based on the bang-bang principle to optimize the energy in multi-boiler for intelligent buildings
